title: Wolf Spririts and Emergent Behavior
body:
Let’s talk about the wolf spirit.

As a default, we want to allow - and encourage - players to find new and surprising ways to play the game. On the flip side, however, we’re always watching for game health issues with emergent gameplay; is this the *only* way to play? Does it come with meaningful tradeoffs? Is there counterplay?

In the case of the Wolf Spirit, the ability to send the spirit on a long and silly journey across the river by smiting the wolf on the opposite side of the jungle has been known to us since **before release** (that is, almost a year and a half ago). We viewed this as a strange but very high cost trick for the jungler - specifically because they would also require very specific compositions (Syndra, Tahm Kench, or Blitzcrank). This was further confirmed in our mind when we saw a few videos, a little discussion, and then nothing thereafter. So we kept it!

Fast forward almost a year, and in patch 5.20 we introduced leashing changes in the form of ‘patience’ where it became a *lot* easier to pull off this trick. We saw some players trying it out and wanted to see how much adoption would pick up - particularly in organized play - before we acted. And… we didn’t see it picked up anywhere once again. So we decided to keep it, again.

As it turns out, however, the lack of adoption of was only artificially true. Due to an unfortunate falloff in communication, we weren’t aware that pros had been *banned* from using the cross-map Wolf Spirit, despite expressing a strong desire to do so. Combine that with the current high community awareness, and we’ve got new facts on the table.

Given how obtuse this trick is to access (for now) and how much demand there is to use this at more organized levels of play, we’re recommending that the Wolf Spirit behavior remain treated as an exploit for competitive play. In 6.4 (unless testing and validation extend that), we’re going to investigate how we can preserve some of the unique play of a ‘spirit across the river,’ but with real support, balance, and clarity.

We understand that this has been very painful for players, and apologize for the confusion in how we handled the situation.

-Fearless

replies.body: When you say it will be treated as an exploit in comptetitive play, does that also apply to normal and ranked games? If I use this trick/bug/strategy in a game is there a risk of me being reported or banned?
Tracking down a concrete answer. Give me a few...
Definitive answer: No. If this gets out of hand, we'll fix/disable stuff to keep the environment fair.
Why is something allowed in normal ranked but not pro?

First thing I can think: Ease of observation. Trying to figure out when it was done in all ranked/normals, who did it, if it was intentional, if they even knew it wasn't allowed would be a nightmare. Doing that for pro games is incredibly simple. If there were an easy way to let every single player know it wasn't allowed AND to "punish" for it, they might have done that. But it's not, sooooooo that's where we are now.
They're not going to punish people for something they let happen. But in competitive, fairness is a priority. Riot hasn't "balanced" this mechanic, so it's not "fair."
entertainment value

Is it intended or is it a bug?

Why did the OCE team got punished for using it if the referees told them it was ok?

And finally, is it related to the warwick rework?

1. It was unintended during development, but known and allowed. 

2. That is being handled by a very different part of Riot, hoping we can get someone with expertise to speak on that. 

3. No.

In development, we had the wolf spirit actually watch over the red side of the jungle if you dragged it there. It caused that the existence of Syndra would basically ruin Poacher's (white smite) due to how jungle paths would naturally play out.

That was our position before we understood that pros hadn't been able to use the behavior freely. It was a known behavior, and we had intentionally not changed it. We are adjusting based on new information.
So it was a known and allowed feature, but not allowed in pro games. Why one and not the other? Why not either just remove it, or just allow it?

We believed it was allowed in pro games, but due to miscommunication, the behavior was banned for pros. 

Now that we better understand the strength of it, we need to either change it or remove it, and we'd rather support the emergent gameplay.

So I will ask, **why** is in banned in pro play but allowed in casual players games?

Based on what I've read in this thread it sounds like the person who made the call to ban pros from using it saw it as an exploit/bug that was too strong to allow, while the Rioters who knew about the bug thought it wasn't a big deal. There wasn't enough communication, hence the miscommunication & conflicting statements

So TL;DR is that you kinda want to keep the option to send the wolf spirit to the enemy jungle but only when it comes with a meaningful tradeoff?

Basically, but there are also game health concerns. If it turns out that the experience of an invading wolf spirit would be oppressive at high frequency, we'd need to change it. This would be true even if the smiting jungler felt a meaningful trade-off.

The problem with this is that the jungler, with absolutely no risk and with very little resource expenditure, gets to confirm that the enemy jungler is or is not on half of the map. Sure, they might be on their Blue side map but in the river, so it does not immediately confirm that the enemy jungler is in their red side jungle for sure if the wolf does not react to their presence in the blue side jungle, but it is reasonable enough to say that if the jungler is not in the blue side jungle but is on the blue side of their map, that within 30 seconds or so the jungler will return to the blue side jungle (and thus trigger the wolf warning). 

All I can see this doing is creating a frustrating experience where potentially every 1:40 (respawn timer on the wolf) the enemy jungler will know where you are with 80% certainty (obviously I don't know the numbers for sure, but you can make strong deductions with this kind of information) and you will (in theory) be unable to pressure the side of the map with the wolf spirit without taking very obscure (and predictable) pathing. Your options for ganking bot lane as a Red Side jungler would be to walk up the mid lane, go through river bush, and go down the river or go through the tri-bush by walking through the raptor's opening or by jumping over dragon wall (edit: or through lane) The only counterplay to the wolf spirit is to counter jungle it (difficult, but doable) or to be noticed by the spirit and have it follow you until it disappears (which wastes time and gives your position away). 

TL:DR unfun mechanic, little counterplay, low cost, no risk, rito pls

Meanwhile, for blue to do this on first clear, blue loses a ton of time and for most of the duration the red bot jungle will likely be empty anyway
